head.title: Avalanche and Stars Tie in Opener

hedline.hl1: Avalanche and Stars Tie in Opener

block.p: The Dallas Stars and Colorado Avalanche played to a 2-2 tie last night in a penalty-filled season opener matching two of the National Hockey League's best goalies and the teams that played in the last two Western Conference finals.

The Dallas Stars and Colorado Avalanche played to a 2-2 tie last night in a penalty-filled season opener matching two of the National Hockey League's best goalies and the teams that played in the last two Western Conference finals.
Ed Belfour stopped 26 Colorado shots and Patrick Roy, who remains four triumphs shy of breaking the N.H.L. record for career victories, made 19 saves.
There were 21 penalties, 11 against Dallas. The visiting Avalanche was 1 for 10 on power plays and Dallas was 1 for 9.

RANGERS SIGN MOTTAU FOR TWO YEARS: The Rangers challenged Mike Mottau to come to camp without a contract and prove he deserved a better offer. Mottau did exactly that, and yesterday the 22-year-old rookie defenseman was rewarded with a two-year deal that included a signing bonus of $575,000.

''I knew something was going to get done today,'' Mottau said after the Rangers practiced in Rye, N.Y., in preparation for their season opener in Atlanta on Saturday. ''It's a great relief. Now, I can get in and get settled and just concentrate on playing, instead of the negotiation headaches I've had since April.''

That was when Mottau, who won the Hobey Baker award - college hockey's equivalent of the Heisman Trophy - at Boston College last season, turned down a $650,000 signing bonus. He also opted to play in the world championships instead of for the Rangers' top minor-league affiliate in Hartford during Hartford's American Hockey League playoff run last season.

After Glen Sather took over as Rangers' president and general manager this summer, the Rangers lowered their bonus offer to Mottau to $550,000. Then, after Mottau excelled in camp following a two-week holdout, the Rangers sweetened the pot.

Yesterday, Mottau agreed to a contract with a base National Hockey League salary of $425,000 this season and $500,000 next season. It Mottau plays in the Minors, his base salary will be $75,000 this season, $82,500 next season.
